366: Whether you realize it or not, you blink around 20 times per minute. You can blink up to 5 times per second if you try, which makes the eyes the fastest muscle in the body.
367: Speaking of ferrets, did you know they used to be used to protect grain stores from rodents?
368: The White House has 35 bathrooms. So every bathroom break can be different for POTUS!
369: The famed "Typhoid Mary" infected more than 50 people by cooking for them.
370: "New car smell" is the scent of dozens of chemicals.
371: The British royal family isn't allowed to play Monopoly because it gets too competitive. The Queen also has only one nail polish color.
372: Ninety percent of the worldâs population lives above the equator.
373: Lawrence has a tattoo that says "H2O" on her hand to remind her to drink water. Whatever works, right?
374: Actor Bill Murray uses a 1-800 number instead of an agent or manager.
375: Baby blue whales grow 200 pounds per day.
376: Slugs have not one, not two, not three... but four noses. They don't work like human noses do, exactly. Instead, they sense chemicals, sounds, lights, and more.
377: The average adult human has 2000-4000 taste buds and despite what you may have been taught, they are not visible to the human eye. Those bumps on your tongue are what the taste buds are on, but those aren't actually the taste buds themselves.
378: Chickens donât just eat seeds, they like to eat insects and also mice and lizards! Ew, chickens!
379: Turns out, a dogâs paw print is just as unique as a humanâs. Good news for dog detectives!
380: Glaciers, ice caps, and ice sheets hold nearly 69 percent of the worldâs freshwater.
381: Creedence Clearwater Revival has the most No. 2 Billboard hits—without ever hitting No. 1.
382: America accidentally dropped an atom bomb on South Carolina in 1958.
383: Goosebumps are meant to ward off predators.
384: In 2016, Mozart sold more albums than BeyoncÃ©.
385: Dogs' noses are like human fingerprints; each one is unique.
386: Dogs' sense of smell is 40 times more powerful than humans' — they have 300 million olfactory receptors.
387: Your fingernails grow faster when you are cold.
388: Jin Songhao of China won the world record for longest skin contact with snow at 46 minutes and 7 seconds!
389: A group of porcupines is called a prickle. How fitting. The animal is also known as a "quill pig" in Latin, which is kind of cute.
390: Sea lions can dance to a beat.
391: Want to know if your pet turtle is a boy or girl? Listen closely! Female turtles hiss and male turtles grunt.
392: Many languages have the same roots.
393: Pope Gregory IV once declared war on cats because he believed Satan used black cats. His declaration lead to the mass extermination of cats.
394: Rolls-Royce makes the most expensive car in the world.
395: Hereâs one to tickle your funny bone: the human hand has 54 bones. Thatâs more than a quarter of the bones in the whole body. Wow!
396: Humans are just one of the estimated 8.7 million species on Earth.
397: Shaq only ever made one three-pointer.
398: Greyhounds can run up to 45 mph. So donât challenge one to a race!
399: The first computer was invented in the 1940s.
401: Spend too much on drinks when you eat out? A small town in Italy actually has a fountain that serves free wine.
402: Before the invention of modern false teeth, dentures were commonly made from the teeth of dead soldiers.
403: Blue Ivy Carter is the youngest person ever to appear on a Billboard chart.
404: The most expensive film ever made was Pirates of the Caribbean, which cost more than 375 million dollars to create.  For reference, the average budget for a big studio movie is around $65 million.
405: Montana has three times as many cows as it does people.
406: It is illegal to sell a "bounceless" pickle to somebody in Connecticut.
407: A flock of ravens is called a conspiracy. Dark stuff!

409: Pigeons can tell the difference between a painting by Monet and Picasso.
410: to learn more fun facts to impress your friends? Check out our coffee facts page and more!
411: Elephants suck on their trunks for comfort.
412: There's a country where twins are most likely to be born.
413: During a fundraiser for Hurricane Katrina relief efforts, someone donated $35,000 so that VH1 Classic would have to play â99 Luftballonsâ on repeat for an entire hour.
414: American Black bears are not just black but include bears of varying colors including blonde, cinnamon, brown, white and even silver-blue.
415: Just like human babies suck their thumbs, baby elephants sometimes suck on their trunks. They can also stand within 20 minutes of birth (though they can't see for a while, and instead sense their mothers through sound and smell).
416: Finland has more saunas than cars. Sounds like a pretty great place. In fact, it's consistently ranked as one of the happiest countries in the world, which makes sense.
417: The oldest living animal is reportedly a Seychelles giant tortoise named Jonathan. He is 190.
418: Some blood vessels in a blue whale are actually big enough for humans to swim through.
419: The Sundance Kid took his nickname from the town of Sundance, Wyoming.
420: Hiking naked is illegal in Switzerland. Though we must say, it doesnât seem like a good idea in general!
421: The average person spends two weeks of their life waiting at traffic lights.
422: Andrew Jacksonâs parrot had to be removed from his funeral because it wouldnât stop swearing. Polly wants her mouth washed out.
423: Harriet Tubman was even more heroic than you thought.
424: Hair and nails grow faster during pregnancy.
425: Women couldnât apply for credit at a bank until 1974.
427: Germany uncovers 2,000 tons of unexploded bombs every year.
428: Australia is wider than the moon — 600km wider, to be exact.
429: Dogs can also breathe and smell simultaneously, unlike humans (have you ever tried to breathe while inhaling through your nose?).
430: Playing the accordion was once required for teachers in North Korea.
431: Though less common than earthquakes, the moon actually has moonquakes, too. That's right. Moonquakes. Pretty much everyone is interested in space, so this is always a good fact to pull out.
432: The unicorn is the national animal of Scotland.
433: You only breathe out of one nostril at a time.
434: All clownfish are born male! They can also all change their sex to female, but they canât turn it back to male after doing so. So Nemo could become a girl fish all along!
435: There's a decorated war hero dog.
436: The height of the Eiffel Tour can vary up to six inches, depending on the temperature.
437: Maine is the only state that borders just one other state.
438: New Yorkâs Central Park is bigger than Monaco. Thatâs right, one park is bigger than an entire country!
439: The surface of Mars is covered in rust, making the planet appear red.
440: Gorillas can catch human colds â youâre probably still safe to go to the zoo with the sniffles, though.
441: The human body contains enough fat to make about seven bars of soap.
442: There may be 2,000 active serial killers in the U.S. right now.
443: The average human body carries more bacteria cells than human cells.
444: Cats are not able to taste anything that is sweet.
445: Beaver bum goo is occasionally used to enhance vanilla flavorings.
447: The Bermuda Triangle isn't any more likely to cause a mysterious disappearance than anywhere else.
448: Bill Gates has donated nearly half his fortune.
449: Most department stores tend to play slower music, in order to slow down customers and keep them shopping longer. The opposite is true for restaurants.
450: You actually lose a large percentage of your taste buds while on an airplane. This might explain a lot about those less-than-stellar in-flight meals, or why you find yourself craving the saltiest foods while in the sky.
451: There's a town in Norway called Hell. Ironically, it never gets very warm there at all. In fact, the temperature regularly dips below zero degrees.
452: One quarter of all our bones are in our feet.
453: Many feet bones don't harden until you're an adult.
454: The place that has more caves than any other place on earth? Kentucky. Surprising, right? Maybe worth adding to your next vacation list.
456: SPAM actually stands for spiced ham. It's been around since 1937.
457: For 100 years, maps have shown an island that doesn't exist.
460: Honey will never go bad, so that's one less thing you have to throw out when you clean out your pantry. You also don't have to refrigerate it.
461: When you look at a bright sky and see white dots, you are looking at your blood.Those are white blood cells.
462: You can eat the labels on fruit. They're totally edible much of the time... they just might not taste that good. Still probably a good idea to peel them off first.
463: The title of tallest Mohawk goes to Kazuhito Watanabe, a Japanese fashion designer. His âhawkâ measures three feet 8.6 inches!
464: Do you have a wacky kiddo who loves random facts?
465: The Supreme Court has its own basketball court, with a great nickname: âThe highest court on the land!â Get it?!
466: In the UK, The Queen legally owns all unmarked swans.
467: âHappy Birthdayâ was the first song ever played on Mars. Mars Rover Curiosity played the song to itself on its first anniversary on the planet.
468: Henry VIII knighted all four of his âGrooms of Stoolâ â the people in charge of wiping his butt for him.
469: The Cleveland Browns are the only team to neither play in or host a Super Bowl.
470: Bo Jackson refused the teams that originally tried to draft him in both baseball and football.
472: Goosebumps developed to make our ancestorsâ hair stand up, making them appear more threatening to predators.
473: Pistachios are technically fruits. Think of them as the opposite of a peach. Instead of throwing out the pit and eating the flesh, we do the opposite with pistachios.
474: The first person convicted of speeding was going eight mph.
475: White chocolate isn't actually chocolate at all. It's mostly cocoa butter, sugar, and lecithin.
476: When Lady Gaga went to NYU, a group of students started a Facebook group about how she would never be famous. Guess the joke is really, really on them now, huh?
477: The severed head of a sea slug can grow a whole new body.
478: Most U.S. stamp adhesive contains about one-tenth of a calorie. British stamps could set you back 5.9 calories. Of course, one lick wonât transfer all of that to your belly.
479: Volleyball and basketball were both invented in Massachusetts.
480: Some Maryland residents are taxed for the rain.
481: The legend of the Loch Ness Monster goes back nearly 1,500 years.
482: The shortest war in history lasted for only 38 minutes.
483: Seven percent of American adults think chocolate milk comes from brown cows (spoiler: It does not).
484: The world's smallest reptile was first reported in 2021.
485: Little brown bats make for the longest nappers â in captivity, they nap up to 19.9 hours a day. Wish we could take a nap that long!
486: Did you know apples come from the same plant family as roses? So do plums, raspberries, and many other delicious fruits. Next time, instead of roses, just send your mother a lovely bouquet of plums!
487: Dogs like squeaky toys for a dark reason.
488: Women are attracted to the scent of Good & Plenty licorice candy and cucumber.
489: A concert promoter once sold a thousand tickets to a Spice Girls concert in Hawaii that was never actually booked. Maybe thatâs where they got the idea for Fyre Fest.
490: The founder of sportswear companies Puma and Adidas were brothers! Rudolf âRudiâ Dassler is the brain behind Puma, while his big bro Adolf âAdiâ Dassler gave the world Adidas.
493: Apparently, the worldâs fastest ant runs faster than Usain Bolt!
494: Only one city has won three major championships in one year. In 1935, the Detroit Lions won the Super Bowl, the Tigers won the world series, and the Red Wings won the Stanley Cup.
495: Some tumors can grow hair, teeth, bones, even fingernails.
496: A tick bite can make you allergic to red meat.
497: The Supreme Court has its own private basketball court called "the highest court in the land." Pretty clever, if you ask us. It also features a full gym.
498: Vatican City is actually the smallest country in the world at only .2 miles wide.
499: You lose up to 30 percent of your taste buds during flight.
501: A flock of flamingos is called a flamboyance.
502: The average person living in Sweden eats about 22 pounds of chocolate a year.
503: Freddie Mercury has a pretty memorable smile. But did you know it's because he had four extra teeth in his upper jaw? Yup. That's why Rami Malek had to wear prosthetic teeth while working on Bohemian Rhapsody.
504: On average, hair grows about 6 inches per year. As we age, some of these hair follicles stop producing hair, which is why hair loss and balding is common in older people.
505: In 2015, Belfast police used ice cream truck music to deter teenage rioters.
506: Your small intestine is the largest internal organ in your body.
507: Tennis was originally played with bare hands.
508: Carrots were originally purple, not orange. You can still find delicious purple carrots around, though, even though they're not the most popular version.
509: Tornados used to be called "twirlblasts" and "twirlwinds" in the 18th century.
511: Ready to have your mind blown? A blind chameleon can still adjust to the colors of its environment. The way it changes colors is because of its special cells, not eyesight.
512: Leo Fender, the inventor of the Stratocaster and the Telecaster, couldnât play guitar.
513: However, George Harrison could reportedly play 26 instruments.
514: Itâs impossible to burp in space.
515: The heads on Easter Island have bodies.
516: George Washington owned a whiskey distillery.
517: Hereâs a little funny and creepy fact: not only are groups of crows called murders, but the birds actually hold funerals for their dead. Spooky!
518: The heaviest onion ever grown was 18 pounds and was grown in England. That's a toddler-sized onion.
519: Your liver can regrow itself in three weeks.
521: Every time you shuffle a deck of cards, you get a combination that's never existed.
522: Tiger shark embryos begin attacking each other in their mother’s womb before they are even born.
523: In Switzerland, it's illegal to own just one guinea pig because they crave social interaction so much. In their natural habitat, they live in groups and are very communicative.
524: The dot over the lower case "i" or "j" is known as a "tittle."
525: Some sea snakes can breathe through their skin.
526: Saint Lucia is the only country in the world named after a woman.
527: It takes a sloth two to four weeks to digest food. They actually have the slowest metabolic system of any mammal.
